studies.title: Metabolic adaptation of diatoms to hypersalinity
studies.description: Microalgae are important primary producers and form the basis for the marine food web. As global climate changes, so do salinity levels that algae are exposed to. A metabolic response of algal cells partly alleviates the resulting osmotic stress. Some metabolites involved in the response are well studied, but the full metabolic implications of adaptation remain unclear. Improved analytical methodology provides an opportunity for additional insight. We can now follow responses to stress in major parts of the metabolome and derive comprehensive charts of the resulting metabolic re-wiring. In this study, we subjected three species of diatoms to high salinity conditions and compared their metabolome to controls in an untargeted manner. The three well-investigated species with sequenced genomes Phaeodactylum tricornutum, Thalassiosira pseudonana and Skeletonema marinoi were selected for our survey. The microalgae react to salinity stress with common adaptations in the metabolome by amino acid up-regulation, production of saccharides and inositols. But also species-specific dysregulation of metabolites is common. Several metabolites previously not connected with osmotic stress reactions are identified, including 4-hydroxyproline, pipecolinic acid, myo-inositol, threonic acid and acylcarnitines. This expands our knowledge about osmoadaptation and calls for further functional characterization of metabolites and pathways in algal stress physiology.

publications.title: Metabolic adaptation of diatoms to hypersalinity
publications.authorList: Vera Nikitashina, Daniel Stettin, Georg Pohnert

protocols.name: Sample collection
protocols.description:
Strains and culture conditions

Strains of Phaeodactylum tricornutum Bohlin (Phaeodactylaceae) CCMP 2561 and Thalassiosira pseudonana Hasle & Heimdal (Thalassiosiraceae) CCMP 1335 were obtained from the Bigelow National Center for Marine Algae and Microbiota (East Boothbay, USA), Skeletonema marinoi Sarno & Zingone (Skeletonemataceae) RCC 75 was obtained from the Roscoff Culture Collection (Roscoff, France). All cultures are maintained in the algae culture collection of the laboratory.


Cultures were grown in 50 mL cell culture flasks containing 40 mL of artificial seawater medium (ASW)[1]. Stock cultures at the stationary phase were used for inoculation. Starting cell densities were 0.025 x 10^6 cells/mL for P. tricornutum and T. pseudonan, and 0.085 x 10^6 cells/mL for S. marinoi. The standard temperature was 13 °C and the light adjusted to 55-65 μmol photons/m^2/s with 14/10 light/dark cycle; all cultures were incubated with shaking at 80 rpm.


Experimental design

Pre-cultures of the algae were grown in triplicates until they reached stationary phase. In total 5 culture replicates were inoculated for each treatment for the salinity stress experiments. ASW media blanks of the same volume were prepared in duplicates for each treatment. Salinity stress was initiated when cultures were at the late log-phase and the endometabolome was extracted 24 and 96 h afterwards.


For P. tricornutum and T. pseudonana, salinity stress was performed by increasing the salt content in the medium from 35 to 60 PSU as described below.


To establish the upper salt concentration in the medium at which S. marinoi could grow, experiments with 3 different salt concentrations of 50, 55, and 60 PSU, were performed. Because negative growth was observed for salt concentrations above 50 PSU, the endometabolome analysis was performed for cultures subjected to the salt increase in the medium to 50 PSU.


Salinity stress experiment

To perform the salinity stress experiments, 5 mL of 35 PSU ASW enriched with either 0.135, 0.180 or 0.225 g/mL of NaCl (Carl Roth, Germany) were added to 40 mL of cultures and media blanks (35 PSU) to reach the final salt concentrations of 50, 55 and 60 PSU, respectively. The same volume of ASW without elevated salt level was added to the control cultures and another set of media blanks. Before addition to the cultures ASW solutions were sterilized by filtration through Filtropur S 0.2 μm filters (Sarstedt AG and Co. KG, Germany).


Ref:

[1] Maier I, Calenberg M. Effect of extracellular Ca2+ and Ca2+-antagonists on the movement and chemoorientation of male gametes of Ectocarpus siliculosus (Phaeophyceae). Botanica Acta. 1994 Dec;107(6):451-60. doi:10.1111/j.1438-8677.1994.tb00820.x.

protocols.name: Extraction
protocols.description:
Extraction of the cultures was performed as described previously[1][2] with modifications. Briefly, after collection of the cells from 40 mL of cultures on Whatman GF/C filters (1.2 μm pore size) (GE Healthcare, US) under vacuum (750 mbar), the endometabolome was extracted by addition of ice-cold extraction mix (1 mL methanol:ethanol:choloroform, 1:3:1, v:v:v) to the filters in 1.5 mL Eppendorf Safe-Lock tubes (Eppendorf Quality, Eppendorf AG, Germany). Cells were disrupted with ultrasonication in an ultrasonic cleaner Emmi-D280 (Emag AG, Germany) for 10 min, and cell debris was sedimented by centrifugation at 30,000 x g at 4 °C for 15 min. Supernatants were transferred in 1.5 mL glass vials. Volumes for GC- and LC-MS samples were normalized according to the cell amounts in the cultures. For the media blanks the average volume of the culture's samples was prepared. The samples were evaporated under vacuum. Dried samples were kept under argon and stored at -20 °C before analysis.


GC-MS

Samples for the GC-MS analysis were prepared as described previously[1][2] with modifications. Briefly, dried samples contained aliquots equivalent to 5 x 10^6 cells and pooled quality control (QC) samples with equal volumes from each extract were reconstituted in 25 μL of pyridine (Chromasolv Plus, Sigma-Aldrich) containing 20 mg/mL methoxyamine monohydrochloride (Sigma-Aldrich), heated at 60 °C for 1 h and incubated at a room temperature overnight. In total 20 μL of samples were transferred into vials with inserts, and to each sample 20 μL of N,O-bis(trimethylsilyl)trifluoroacetamide (Thermo) were added. To one QC samples 1 μL of a C7-C40 alkane standard mix, 100 μg/mL in hexane (diluted 1:10 from the 1 mg/mL standard from Sigma-Aldrich) was added. Samples were heated at 60 °C for 1 h and directly measured.


For GC-MS measurement, samples of standards were dried under vacuum and derivatised in the same way as experimental samples. Final concentrations of standards made up 100 μg/mL. To 40 μL of each standard sample 1 μL of a C7-C40 alkane standard mix, 100 μg/mL in hexane was added (final concentration of C7-C40 alkane standard mix was 2.44 μg/mL).


LC-MS

For the LC-MS analysis aliquots equivalent to 3 x 10^6 cells and pooled quality control (QC) samples with equal volumes from each extract were reconstituted in 150 µL of the mixture of methanol:acetonitrile:water (5:9:1, v:v:v).


For LC-MS measurement, solutions of the standards were prepared by dissolving the standard in a mixture of methanol:acetonitrile:water (5:9:1, v:v:v) with the final concentration of 1 mg/mL. Nγ-acetyldiaminobutyrate and cysteinolic acid were dissolved in water.


Standards

List of standards used for GC- and LC-MS measurements: 5-oxo-Proline, citric acid, ectoin, erythrose, L-methionine, myo-inositol, putrescine dihydrohydrochloride, sedoheptulose, pentadecanoic acid methyl ester (Sigma Aldrich); betaine, isovalerylcarnitine, mannose, N,N-dimethylarginine, Acetylcarnitine hydrochloride, butyrylcarnitine, propionylcarnitine (Sigma); methyl palmitate, turanose (HPC Standards GmbH); DL-methionine sulfoxide, stachydrine (Fluorochem); 4-hydroxyproline, asparagine, L-arginine monohydrochloride, L-asparagine monohydrate, L-glutamine, L-isoleucine, L-leucine, L-lysine, L-phenylalanine, L-proline, L-serine, L-threonine, L-tyrosine, L-valine, tryptophan, xylose (Fluka analytical); adenosine, arginine methyl ester dihydrochloride, D-cellobiose, N-acetyl glucosamine, pipecolinic acid, L-threonic acid hemicalcium salt (AlfaAesar); ribose (Aldrich Chemistry); glucose, L-ornithine, L-homoserine (ABCR GmbH); pyrrole-2-carboxylic acid (Acros Organics, Thermo Scientific); sorbose (Dr. Ehrenstorfer GmbH); N(gamma)-acetyldiaminobutyrate (Chem-Impex int'l inc); allose (Carl Roth GmbH); fructose (Applichem GmbH); cysteinolic acid.


Refs:

[1] Vidoudez C, Pohnert G. Comparative metabolomics of the diatom Skeletonema marinoi in different growth phases. Metabolomics. 2012 Aug;8:654-69. doi:10.1007/s11306-011-0356-6.

[2] Stettin D, Poulin RX, Pohnert G. Metabolomics Benefits from Orbitrap GC-MS-Comparison of Low- and High-Resolution GC-MS. Metabolites. 2020 Apr 4;10(4):143. doi:10.3390/metabo10040143. PMID:32260407.

protocols.name: Chromatography
protocols.description:
GC-MS

GC-MS measurements were performed on a Q-Exactive Orbitrap mass spectrometer connected to a Trace 1310 Gas Chromatograph with a TriPlus RSH Autosampler (Thermo Scientific, Bremen, Germany). The gas chromatograph was equipped with a Zebron ZB-SemiVolatiles column (30 m x 0.25 mm x 0.25 μm, Phenomenex, USA). Helium was used as a carrier gas with a flow rate of 1 mL/min.


Due to the high intensity of the proline peak at the beginning of the GC chromatogram, split ratios had to be high enough to not overload column and detector. However, detection of low concentrated metabolites was limited at those split ratios. To circumvent this, all samples were injected twice and measured with 2 different methods. The first method ('Proline method') was run at a sufficiently high split rate to detect proline without overloading the system and MS-acquisition was terminated after elution of proline. The second method ('After proline method') was run with a lower split ratio, the same temperature gradient, but acquisition started after the elution of proline. For data analysis, preprocessed data for both measurements were combined, with data up to retention time of proline taken from the first measurement and data after retention time of proline taken from the second one.


Altogether 2 different programs were applied for measurement of the samples, program 1 was used in the 'Proline method': The initial temperature 80 °C was maintained for 2 min, rose to 120 °C at a rate of 20 °C/min, maintained for 1 min, rose to 135 °C at a rate of 5 °C/min, rose to 320 °C at a rate of 125 °C/min and maintained for 7 min. Program 2 was used for 'After proline method' and 'QC method': The initial temperature 80 °C was maintained for 2 min, rose to 120 °C at a rate of 20 °C/min, maintained for 1 min, rose to 250 °C at a rate of 5 °C/min, rose to 320 °C at a rate of 10 °C/min and maintained for 2 min. The difference between the two temperature programs is due to the fact that the program for 'Proline method' is used to acquire data only until RT of proline, and is then followed by a post-run bakeout. Method 'After proline method' and 'QC method' follow the same temperature gradient since data acquisition for 'QC method' continues beyond RT of proline and for 'After proline method' starts at this point, temperature gradients for both methods continue until 40 min.


LC-MS

Samples for LC-MS analysis were measured with a Dionex Ultimate 3000 system coupled to a Q-Exactive Plus Orbitrap mass spectrometer (Thermo Scientific, Bremen, Germany). The duration of the method was 14.5 min with an MS runtime from 0.5 to 9.0 min. Separation of the samples was performed on a SeQuant ZIC-HILIC column (5 µm, 200 Å, 150 x 2.1 mm, Merck, Germany), equipped with SeQuant ZIC-HILIC guard column (20 x 2.1 mm, Merck, Germany). Eluent A consisted of water with 2% acetonitrile and 0.1% formic acid, eluent B of 90% acetonitrile with 10% water and 1 mmol/L ammonium acetate. The flow rate was set to 0.6 mL/min, the gradient started with 85% solvent B which was held for 4.0 min, gradient to 0% of solvent B (4.0-5.0 min), hold 0% B (5.0-9.0 min), gradient to 100% B (9.0-10.0 min), hold 100% B (10.0-12.0 min), gradient to 85% B (12.0-12.5 min), hold 85% B (12.5-14.5 min).

protocols.name: Mass spectrometry
protocols.description:
GC-MS

For the electron ionization (EI) mode temperature of the injector was 250 °C, transfer line 250 °C, the auxiliary zone 280 °C and the ion source 300 °C. For the chemical ionization (CI) mode temperature of the ion source was 180 °C, methane was used as an ionization gas with a flow rate of 1.5 mL/min. The injected volume of samples was 1 µL, for EI mode split ratio varied (Table S1 in the paper associated with this study), for CI mode split was changed to splitless mode. Data were recorded in full scan profile mode across a mass range from 50 to 600 m/z in EI mode. Full scan profile mode with a mass range from 80 to 1000 m/z was used for the CI mode, the ionization energy was 70 eV.


All samples were injected twice and measured with 2 different methods. The first method ('Proline method') was run at a sufficiently high split rate to detect proline without overloading the system. The second method ('After proline method') was run with a lower split ratio, the same temperature gradient, but acquisition starting after the elution of the proline peak. Retention time of proline was 7.6 min for P. tricornutum samples and 7.9 min for T. pseudonana and S. marinoi samples (RT of proline). QC samples were used to trace reproducibility of metabolite response over the whole measurement sequence and to establish normalized retention times via retention time standards. For this reason, QC samples were measured in a single run at a fixed split ratio ('QC method'). The third method was applied to measure entire sample. The first and second methods were applied for single samples. QC samples with retention time standards in both EI and CI modes were measured in a single run.


The order of the samples’ measurements was randomized within samples from one extraction timepoint. Pooled QC samples were measured at the beginning and every 5 samples for the purpose of signal drift correction. For samples measured twice, the 'After proline method' was run before the 'Proline method'.


LC-MS

MS and MS/MS measurements were conducted within the scan range from 80 to 1200 m/z with resolution 70,000. MS measurements were performed in positive and negative modes (polarity switching) with resolution 70,000. MS/MS measurements were performed separately for positive and negative modes using parallel reaction monitoring, 3-stepped normalized collision energy 15, 30 and 45 were applied.


MS1 measurements were conducted with the following settings: automatic gain control target 3E6, the maximum ion injection time 200 ms, and scan range from 80 to 1200 m/z. Single samples and QC samples for relative standard deviation correction were measured simultaneously with positive and negative modes with resolution 70,000. Moreover, QC samples were measured with higher resolution 280,000, in positive and negative mode separately.


The order of measurement for samples from 2 timepoints was randomized, QC samples for relative standard deviation correction were measured every 5 samples for signal drift correction.


MS2 measurements were performed for compounds detected in the MS1 data with Compound Discoverer version 3.1 (Thermo Fisher Scientific) applying standard workflow (Untargeted Metabolomics with Statistics Detect Unknowns with ID Using Online Databases and mzLogic) with default settings. The measurements were performed separately for positive and negative modes using parallel reaction monitoring. The duration time and runtime were the same as for the MS1 measurement, the settings were as followed: automatic gain control target 2E5, maximum ion injection time 100 ms, 3-stepped normalized collision energy 15, 30 and 45, scan range from 80 to 1200 m/z, resolution 70,000, in profile mode.

protocols.name: Data transformation
protocols.description:
GC-MS

GC-MS data pre-processing was performed as described previously[1]. Briefly, raw files were converted into .mzXML format using Proteowizard Suite (proteowizard.sourceforge.net) with vendor peak picking enabled. Data were pre-processed with R script[1] which includes XCMS package[2], CAMERA package[3] and MetaMS package[4]. Obtained data was processed further with StatTarget package[5] for quality control based signal drift correction. All settings were used as published except minimum fragments for features grouping was set to 5[1].


LC-MS

LC-MS data obtained raw data were preprocessed using Compound Discoverer version 3.1 (Thermo Fisher Scientific). The standard workflow (Untargeted Metabolomics with Statistics Detect Unknowns with ID Using Online Databases and mzLogic) with default settings was applied. Peak picking and deconvolution were performed for each algae species experiment separately.


Statistical analysis

Statistical analysis was performed for signals of which the average peak area of treated or control cultures was at least 5 times higher than in blank samples. Statistical analysis was conducted using Metaboanalyst 4.0[6]. Data was log-transformed and auto-scaled. Statistically significantly dysregulated compounds were detected using volcano plots with fold change more than 2 and false discovery rate adjusted p-value less than 0.05 with unequal group variance.


Refs:

[1] Stettin D, Poulin RX, Pohnert G. Metabolomics Benefits from Orbitrap GC-MS-Comparison of Low- and High-Resolution GC-MS. Metabolites. 2020 Apr 4;10(4):143. doi:10.3390/metabo10040143. PMID:32260407.

[2] Smith CA, Want EJ, O'Maille G, Abagyan R, Siuzdak G. XCMS: processing mass spectrometry data for metabolite profiling using nonlinear peak alignment, matching, and identification. Anal Chem. 2006 Feb 1;78(3):779-87. doi:10.1021/ac051437y. PMID:16448051.

[3] Kuhl C, Tautenhahn R, Böttcher C, Larson TR, Neumann S. CAMERA: an integrated strategy for compound spectra extraction and annotation of liquid chromatography/mass spectrometry data sets. Anal Chem. 2012 Jan 3;84(1):283-9. doi:10.1021/ac202450g. Epub 2011 Dec 12. PMID:22111785;.

[4] Wehrens R, Weingart G, Mattivi F. metaMS: an open-source pipeline for GC-MS-based untargeted metabolomics. J Chromatogr B Analyt Technol Biomed Life Sci. 2014 Sep 1;966:109-16. doi:10.1016/j.jchromb.2014.02.051. Epub 2014 Mar 12. PMID:24656939.

[5] Luan H, Ji F, Chen Y, Cai Z. statTarget: A streamlined tool for signal drift correction and interpretations of quantitative mass spectrometry-based omics data. Anal Chim Acta. 2018 Dec 7;1036:66-72. doi:10.1016/j.aca.2018.08.002. Epub 2018 Aug 6. PMID:30253838.

[6] Chong J, Soufan O, Li C, Caraus I, Li S, Bourque G, Wishart DS, Xia J. MetaboAnalyst 4.0: towards more transparent and integrative metabolomics analysis. Nucleic Acids Res. 2018 Jul 2;46(W1):W486-W494. doi:10.1093/nar/gky310. PMID:29762782.

protocols.name: Metabolite identification
protocols.description:
GC-MS

Identification of unknowns detected with GC-MS analysis was conducted using the NIST 2011 Mass Spectral Library database (National Institute of Standards and Technology, USA), MetFrag[1] and MS-Finder platforms[2]. The quality of detected peaks and their intensities on the chromatogram were checked manually.


Since EI spectra in Orbitrap GC/MS often lack the molecular ion, we supported the identification of candidate metabolites by additional CI-measurements. The CI mass spectra were checked for the presence of molecular ions -CH4 neutral loss and +C2H5 and +C3H4 adducts to confirm the elemental composition.


The final verification of unknowns was done by comparison of mass spectra and retention index (accepted difference ≤3 units) with analytical standards.


LC-MS

Identification of unknowns detected with LC-MS analysis was performed using Sirius version 4.4.29[3]. Depending both on the tree fragmentation score[4] and the percentage of CSI:FingerID tool[5] putative identification of unknowns was performed.


The identity of unknowns was established by comparison of retention time and MS1 spectra with chemical standards (accepted difference ≤0.2 min, <5 ppm). For betaine, pipecolinic acid, cysteinolic acid, methionine sulfoxide, N,N-dimethylarginine, ectoine, Nγ-acetyldiaminobutyrate, acetylcarnitine, propionylcarnitine, butyrylcarnitine and isovalerylcarnitine also MS2 spectra for both external and internal standards were recorded and compared manually.


Refs:

[1] Ruttkies C, Schymanski EL, Wolf S, Hollender J, Neumann S. MetFrag relaunched: incorporating strategies beyond in silico fragmentation. J Cheminform. 2016 Jan 29;8:3. doi:10.1186/s13321-016-0115-9. PMID:26834843.

[2] Tsugawa H, Kind T, Nakabayashi R, Yukihira D, Tanaka W, Cajka T, Saito K, Fiehn O, Arita M. Hydrogen Rearrangement Rules: Computational MS/MS Fragmentation and Structure Elucidation Using MS-FINDER Software. Anal Chem. 2016 Aug 16;88(16):7946-58. doi:10.1021/acs.analchem.6b00770. Epub 2016 Aug 4. PMID:27419259.

[3] Dührkop K, Fleischauer M, Ludwig M, Aksenov AA, Melnik AV, Meusel M, Dorrestein PC, Rousu J, Böcker S. SIRIUS 4: a rapid tool for turning tandem mass spectra into metabolite structure information. Nat Methods. 2019 Apr;16(4):299-302. doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0344-8. Epub 2019 Mar 18. PMID:30886413.

[4] Böcker S, Dührkop K. Fragmentation trees reloaded. J Cheminform. 2016 Feb 1;8:5. doi:10.1186/s13321-016-0116-8. PMID:26839597.

[5] Dührkop K, Shen H, Meusel M, Rousu J, Böcker S. Searching molecular structure databases with tandem mass spectra using CSI:FingerID. Proc Natl Acad Sci U S A. 2015 Oct 13;112(41):12580-5. doi:10.1073/pnas.1509788112. Epub 2015 Sep 21. PMID:26392543.
